_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Release Prevention and Response Policy

     In compliance with the provisions of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68,
the Queen Anne's County Sanitary District has prepared an Integrated Process Safety and Risk
Management Plan for the Kent Narrows-Stevensville-Grasonville (KNSG) Wastewater
Treatment Plant at Stevensville, Maryland It is the policy of the Sanitary District to operate all of
the water and wastewater treatment facilities within its jurisdiction in the safest and most
efficient manner possible, with due regard for the health and safety of the Sanitary District
employees, the Public, and our environment.

Stationary Source and Chemicals

     The Kent Narrows-Stevensville-Grasonville (KNSG) Wastewater Treatment Plant at
Stevensville employs gaseous chlorine for the disinfection of the wastewater.  Sulfur dioxide is
used to dechlorinate the disinfected effluent prior to discharge to the environment.  This is
considered to be a single, continuous process.  The gasses are delivered, stored, and drawn from
one-ton containers. The Emergency Response Plan has been in existence since 1991 and is
coordinated with the local emergency response organizations.

Release Scenarios

     The worst case scenario assumes the Environmental Protection Agency mandated
elements as defined in 40 CFR 68.  The basis for the calculation is the release of one ton (2000
pounds) of chlorine or sulfur dioxide ( greatest quantity held in a single vessel) at 0 feet
elevation, 100 degrees Fahrenheit, 10 minutes duration, with an atmospheric stability class F.

     The Alternative scenario assumes the same quantity, a break in the gas withdrawal tubing
at the tank connection, a temperature of 77.33xF (the mean monthly maximum, at the closest
reporting station, for 5 years 1992 to 1996), and an atmospheric stability of D.  This simulates a
spring or summer day that may occur with children occupying neighboring schools. 

Release Prevention

The general release prevention program is based on training and material selection.  The
operating personnel are trained in the proper operation, maintenance, connection-disconnection,
and emergency response for the chemicals employed at the Kent Narrows-Stevensville-
Grasonville (KNSG) Wastewater Treatment Plant.  The two chemicals a similar enough that the
operations are essentially the same.

     All gas-containing tubing and control devices are selected for specific material
compatibility and Code and Standard compliance.  The systems are regularly and routinely
inspected and maintenance performed as appropriate.  The two gas handling systems have been
completely rebuilt since the original construction.
     The KNSG Wastewater Treatment Plant will be undergoing an expansion which will
include the replacement of gaseous chlorine disinfection with ultraviolet light disinfection.  This
replacement will also eliminate the need for sulfur dioxide dechlorination.  It is expected that all
listed chemicals will be removed by July 31, 2001.

Accident History

     To date, there have been no accidental releases resulting in either employee injury on-site,
or with off-site consequences.

Emergency Response Program

     The Emergency Response Program is based on the use of KNSG WWTP employees
trained  to respond to, and control, an accidental release of either chlorine or sulfur dioxide.  The
employees are trained in the use of Personal Protective Equipment and specialized ton-container
patching kits.  There is no chemical emergency or hazardous materials response organization,
either public or commercial, off-site within a reasonable distance or response time.
